statement:
If $\mathcal{C}$ is a category, write $\hat{\mathcal{C}}$ for the
category of contravariant functors from $\mathcal{C}$ to ${\bf Sets}$,
the category of sets. The morphisms in $\hat{\mathcal{C}}$ are natural
transformations of functors.

(To avoid set theoretical concerns, one can take a universe
$\mathcal{U}$ and take all categories to be $\mathcal{U}$-small.)

For any object $X$ of $\mathcal{C}$, $h_X = {\rm Hom}(-,X)$ is a
contravariant functor from $\mathcal{C}$ to ${\bf Sets}$, and therefore
is an object of $\hat{\mathcal{C}}$.

*Yoneda Lemma* says that $X\mapsto h_X$ is a covariant functor
$\mathcal{C}\to\hat{\mathcal{C}}$, which embeds $\mathcal{C}$ faithfully
as a full subcategory of $\hat{\mathcal{C}}$. This embedding is called
the *Yoneda embedding*.
